did.unittitle: J. Scott Odell folk music collection

origination.label: source
origination.corpname: National Museum of American History (U.S.). Division of Musical History

did.abstract: The J. Scott Odell folk music collection (1945-2016, inclusive) contains AV recordings, photographs, correspondence, writings, and other materials relating to Odell's career at the Smithsonian as a musical instrument conservator and researcher of American music traditions. The collection largely consists of materials relating to Odell's research trips (often combined with personal visits) throughout the Eastern United States. Research strengths of the collection include the history of the Appalachian dulcimer and banjo, the Smithsonian Folkways project "Black Banjo Songsters," musician and poet Burt Porter, and the Bread and Puppet Theater.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Jay Scott Odell (b. 1935) was born in St. Paul, Minnesota, to Adalberta Lavoie Odell and Jay Geddes Odell. The family moved frequently throughout his childhood, resulting in Odell having lived at fourteen different addresses and attending seven different schools by the time he graduated high school in 1953. When the family settled in Mamaroneck, New York, in 1950, Odell met poet Peter Kane Dufault, and musician and poet Burt Porter, two figures who would go on to strongly influence his personal and professional development. It was on the advice of Dufault, for example, that Odell apprenticed with harpsichord-maker William Dowd after college.

Odell attended Middlebury College where he met his future wife, Dorothy "Dottie" Hiebert. After graduating in 1957, Hiebert moved to France and Odell took a position on the boat of Dutch writer Jan DeHartog before joining Hiebert to travel Europe. By 1959, they had returned to the United States (Boston, Massachusetts) and married. It was at this point in their lives that they became active in the peace movement and the early Folk Revival. Odell's relationship with Burt Porter continued, and he developed contacts with other musicians including Peter and Polly Gott, Tom "Tom Banjo" Azarian, Mike Seeger, and Tracy Schwartz. The Odells also became involved with the Bread and Puppet Theater group, founded by Peter and Elka Schumann, which established its primary location in Glover, Vermont, near Porter's property.

Odell is particularly notable for his work in musical instrument conservation at the Smithsonian Institution and his involvement in the development of the Smithsonian Folklife Festival. In 1963, following his harpsichord apprenticeship with William Dowd, Odell was hired by the Smithsonian as a musical instrument conservator. Under Cynthia Hoover and C. Malcolm Watkins, he established a restoration workshop for musical instruments at the National Museum of History and Technology, now the National Museum of American History. Over the course of his career, Odell served not only as a conservator but also as head of a technical laboratory and, eventually, as the first director of conservation at the National Museum of American History.

Odell was a key figure in the shifting philosophy of the musical instrument department regarding its collections and acquisition practices. With Hoover, Odell helped establish and facilitate a concert series with the mission of "[taking] the instruments out of their cases and [letting] them sing" – a major innovation in museum programming. Odell's commitment to bringing music history and traditions to life manifested in the expansion of the Smithsonian concert series, his relationship with Ralph Rinzler, and his early involvement with the Festival of American Folklife, now the Smithsonian Folklife Festival.

Although his professional training was in working with historical keyboard instruments, Odell's lifelong interest in traditional and regional music had a significant impact on his career. Between 1964 and 1977, when Odell was head of the laboratory at the Smithsonian Institution's Division of Musical Instruments, he undertook a series of collecting trips throughout the Eastern United States to expand the Division's collection of traditional American instruments.

In 1964, Odell and Porter attended the Annual Galax Old Time Fiddlers Convention. Following this initial trip, Hoover and Watkins supported Odell's efforts to, in addition to acquiring objects for the collection, research and record the cultural contexts of those instruments. Over the course of these trips, Odell built personal relationships with many of the musicians and craftspeople with whom he worked, including the Melton-Russell family, Tommy Jarrell, and Fred Cockerham.

Odell retired in 1993, but continued contract work at the Smithsonian. Working for the National Museum of American History, he assisted with the care and description of the Museum's banjo collection, as well as the acquisition of the Grimes and Jeffries dulcimer collection. He has also maintained associations with the Smithsonian Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage. In 1998, Odell co-produced a record through Smithsonian Folkways with folklorist Cecelia Conway titled "Black Banjo Songsters," which focused on the African American banjo tradition and featured many of the artists with whom Odell had built relationships.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in eight series as follows: (1) Correspondence, 1963-1978; (2) Folk Instruments Research; (3) Collected Publications and Ephemera; (4) Collecting Trips; (5) Publications; (6) Sound Recordings; (7) Oversize Materials; and (8) Accruals. Within each series and subseries, folders are arranged thematically, alphabetically, and/or chronologically.

Series 1-7 reflect the order of the original transfer from the Archives Center, National Museum of American History. Series 8 (Accruals) encompasses several deposits made by Scott Odell of additional materials between 2011 and 2017. Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives staff, in collaboration with Odell, imposed order upon Series 8.

Researchers should note that, when performing research in Series 8 (Accruals), they might need to consult multiple boxes, even when working within a single subseries where the intellectual arrangement in the finding aid does not always align with the physical arrangement of the materials. This separation between the intellectual and physical arrangement is due in part to the order in which RRFAC received each deposit, the format of the materials (i.e., papers vs. photographs vs. AV items), and earlier digitization efforts.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access to the Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives and Collections is by appointment only. Visit our website for more information on scheduling a visit or making a digitization request. Researchers interested in accessing born-digital records or audiovisual recordings in this collection must use access copies.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Permission to publish materials from the collection must be requested from the Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives and Collections. Please visit our website to learn more about submitting a request. The Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives and Collections make no guarantees concerning copyright or other intellectual property restrictions. Other usage conditions may apply; please see the Smithsonian's Terms of Use for more information.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Transferred from the Division of Musical History to the Archives Center, National Museum of American History on 02/23/89.
Transferred from the Archives Center, National Museum of American History, to the Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage on 05/29/08.
Significant deposits of additional materials to the Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives made by Scott Odell in 2011 and 2016. Smaller deposits made intermittantly between 2011 and 2017.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Materials relating to Odell's career at the Smithsonian can also be found in the Smithsonian Institution Archives (SIA), particularly in the records of the NMAH Musical History Division.

Materials relating to the Bread and Puppet Theater can also be found in the archives of the Bread and Puppet Theater (via the Internet Archive); the University of Vermont; and the University of California, Davis.

scopecontent.head: Scope/Contents note
scopecontent.p: The J. Scott Odell Folk Music Collection, which includes materials dating from 1945-2016, documents the research, professional work, and personal relations of J. Scott Odell (b. 1935). Odell worked at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History (NMAH) as a musical instrument conservator and traveled throughout the Eastern United States documenting a variety of musical instruments and traditions. The collection reflects his research trips and other travels; the development of exhibits and performance of music and dance at the Smithsonian; and the relationships Odell developed with the musicians, craftspeople, informants, and other people he worked with throughout his career.

Research strengths of this collection include notes, photographs, and recordings from Odell's fieldwork; extensive documentation of Odell's work on the Smithsonian Folkways project Black Banjo Songsters, in collaboration with folklorist Cecelia Conway; and materials pertaining to the Bread and Puppet Theater (based in Glover, Vermont). Significant places documented include southwest Virginia (Galax), nearby North Carolina (Shelton-Laurel), the surrounding tri-state area, and Vermont (Glover). Significant individuals represented in the collection include Odell, Burt Porter, Ralph Rinzler, and other well-known musicians. The most prominent instrument information in the collection relates to the banjo and the Appalachian dulcimer, although the American fiddle tradition and other instruments are also represented. Materials include photographs (negatives and prints), field notes, trip reports, correspondence, slides, writings, and AV materials. This collection may also be of interest to researchers of AV history and evolution. The wide variety of formats found in the collection maps the development of popular recording media. The collection includes open-reel tapes, Hi-8 tapes, DATs, mini-DV tapes, Betacam and Betacam SP tapes, VHS and SVHS tapes, cassettes, optical discs, mini-discs, and Zip discs.

This collection was initially established in 2008, when it was transferred from Archives Center at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History (NMAH) to the Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives & Collections (RRFAC), Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage (CFCH). (NMAH Archives Center had received the collection from the Division of Musical History.) Since 2008, the collection has been significantly expanded, more than doubling in size between 2008 and 2016. (These additional materials can be found in Series 8, Accruals.) With these deposits, the scope of the collection expanded beyond Odell's Appalachian dulcimer research and instrument conservator duties to include his banjo research, travels, relationships with musicians (particularly Burt Porter), and involvement with the Bread and Puppet Theater.

odd.head: Shared Stewardship of Collections
odd.p: The Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage acknowledges and respects the right of artists, performers, Folklife Festival participants, community-based scholars, and knowledge-keepers to collaboratively steward representations of themselves and their intangible cultural heritage in media produced, curated, and distributed by the Center. Making this collection accessible to the public is an ongoing process grounded in the Center's commitment to connecting living people and cultures to the materials this collection represents. To view the Center's full shared stewardship policy, which defines our protocols for addressing collections-related inquiries and concerns, please visit https://doi.org/10.25573/data.21771155.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 8 consists of accrued materials donated to the Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives since 2011. The materials have been organized in eight subseries: Biographical Material (8.1), Black Banjo Songsters (8.2), Bread and Puppet Theater (8.3), Individuals (8.4), Music Instrument Research (8.5), Porter, Burt (8.6), Smithsonian Folklife Festival (8.7), and Vermont (8.8).

Subseries divisions reflect Odell's private and professional activities during and after his career at the Smithsonian, with some individuals and activities appearing in multiple subseries. The order imposed upon the accrued materials was established by the processing archivists in frequent collaboration with Odell.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of photos, slides, AV material, papers, and ephemera related to the Odell family. This subseries reflects Odell's personal travels, hobbies, and history, although it frequently overlaps with Odell's concurrent personal and professional activities. This subseries contains a significant amount of photographs and other documentation relating to falconry.

This subseries also contains recordings, photographs, writings, correspondence, ephemera, and other materials relating to Odell's career at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History, including various Smithsonian events such as concerts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of fieldwork conducted by Odell and folklorist Cecelia Conway from the 1970s to the 1990s and production material associated with the 1998 Smithsonian Folkways release "Black Banjo Songsters." Materials include notes, correspondence, research material, photographs, and AV materials related to the project. This subseries also contains materials relating to other projects, including a TV show, "Way Out West" and the forthcoming Smithsonian Folkways release "Black Banjo Songsters II".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tapes are about the Smithsonian Folklife Festival, Prism Coffeehouse, Black Banjo and interviews with John Jackson, Archie Edwards, Rufus Kasey, Mike Seeger, Leonard Bowles, Joe Thompson.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Kip Lornell, Chuck Perdue, and others started putting together TV program "Way Out West" (never produced) and was going to be narrated by Chuck Perdue. It is a video with African American musicians in central and southwest Virginia, which begins with a square dance by the Bowles family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of artwork, AV materials, papers, and photographic material related to art and performances by the Bread and Puppet Theater group. Odell and his friend Burt Porter were supporters, audience members, occasional group performers, and friends with founders Peter and Elka Schumann. The bulk of the material relates to Bread and Puppet activities in Glover, Vermont, especially performances of "Our Domestic Resurrection Circus."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains artwork of the Bread and Puppet Theater group in various formats, including announcements and stories, song sheets and songbooks ("The Stations of the Cross").

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains artwork of the Bread and Puppet Theater group such as broadsides, comics, and pamphlets, including "Hallelujah," the "Why Cheap Art Manifesto," and event announcements. The file also includes one letter-sized photo of an unidentified performance showing Peter Schumann as Uncle Sam on stilts among other group members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains blank postcards and leaflets by the Bread and Puppet Theater group, showing both original artwork and photographs of performances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains original artwork by the Bread and Puppet Theater in various formats, including drawings, photos, event announcements, hand drawn maps, and zines featuring stories, one of which is written in Italian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains purchased programs of Bread and Puppet performances, including a copy of an envelope with handwritten notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains pages of handwritten audio logs of a recorded Our Domestic Resurrection Circus performance by the Bread and Puppet Theater group. The recording is housed in the folder "AV material - Circus and Pageant".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains correspondence related to personal matters and falconry, including a statement after Dufault's death related to his life's work, and two poems by Dufault published in The New Yorker in 1970. Peter Kane Dufault, a friend from Mamaroneck (1956/57), gave Odell the advice to work for harpsichord maker William Dowd in Boston, MA.

Accompanying publications are located in oversize Box 17. All articles were written by Peter Kane Dufault during his time at the Greene County Examiner Recorder. Articles mentioned in the letter from November 1961 are grouped together.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains personal correspondence between the Gott and Odell families (including letters between children), some undated but probably from the 1960s. Includes a hand drawn map to the Gott's home (circa 1996 [audio interview with Odell STE-012]) and a family photo glued to the Christmas Card of 1972. Correspondence references George Landers, Burt Porter, and others. Includes the publication "Building the Traditional Hewn-Log Home" by Peter Gott and David Peterson (1987).
Other correspondence with Peter Gott (1964 - 1965) can be found within series 1, box 1, folder 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains correspondence and ephemera, including the Blue Ridge Music Association Newsletter from March 1970, and August - October 1989, and an article by The Evening Star in 1970. The letters contain thoughts on family matters, dulcimer-making, performances, and references of mutual acquaintances (Kyle Creed and others). One letter by Bonnie Russell to Odell (1983) is housed in, box 4, folder 3.
Newspaper articles by The Washington Post and Galax Gazette featuring performances of the Russell family in 1970 are in oversize Box 17.
Other correspondence with the Melton Family (1965 - 1968) and Roscoe Russell (1968 - 1976) can be found in series 1, box 1, folder 11 and 14.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of recordings, photographs, correspondence, field notes, ephemera, and a variety of other materials relating to Odell's career researching musical instruments and their associated traditions and cultures. The bulk of these materials relate to research concentrating on American music traditions, particularly banjos and dulcimers.
Other records on Odell's fieldwork, including trip reports and field notes can be found in Series 4: Collecting Trips, 1964-1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains memoranda of calls and correspondence with multiple partners, including John Tyrell (The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians), Elias Kaufman (American Banjo Fraternity 5 Stringer), George S. Gregory, John W. Perry (University of the Witwaterstrand, Johannesburg), W.H. McMichael, Robert G. Fredway, David Polacheck, Tom Brown, Philip Kennedy, Mrs. Dale McCauley, Paul Stoner, Thomas Adler, John F. Garst (The University of Georgia), Charles L. Perdue Jr. (University of Virginia), Josiah Hatch, Judith Fuller (Dallas Historical Society, includes photos), Kyle Creed (copies related to accession in the United States National Museum) regarding Odell's research and expertise as a conservation specialist. Some correspondence also relates to other research topics, such as dulcimers.

Conversations occasionally mention personal matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains the manuscript of a talk Odell held at the Afro-American Historical and Genealogical Society Annual Meeting, April 2002, called "The African American Banjo: America's First Musical Instrument."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains handwritten and typed notes, including bibliographies, correspondences, and one photo, referring to literature research, calls, and meetings, including cross-references to other research topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains handwritten notes, printed bibliographies, and a postcard, referring to literature research, calls, and meetings, including cross-references to other research topics. The file also contains a manuscript with notes, and the final version of a talk given by Odell "The African American Banjo: America's First Musical Instrument". The file also contains two photos of Odell related to his Banjo research, one showing him performing at the African American Heritage Day in 2001 with Jim Rosenstock, and one in which Odell is holding a banjo, with a handwritten note by Cecelia Conway on the back, thanking Odell for guest teaching one of her classes in 1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains publications and copies of publications, some with handwritten notes, related to Odell's banjo research, including articles from the Los Angeles County Museum Quarterly Vol. 7 (1949), a brochure of the ODE company, a list of American Banjo Makers by Steve Trussel, The Galpin Society Journal's summary of contents, a printout of an online article "Banjo Prices of the Twenties," The Tuckahoe Review Vol. 1 Issue 2, a printout of an article on Ray Andrews, American Heritage, an article on "The Origins of Banjo Music in Britain and Bristol" (unidentified publication), a collection of resources on O.H.Gibson, "Masters of the Banjo," the program for a "Conference for African Americans Researching their Family Histories," a leaflet for the African American Heritage Day on The National Colonial Farm, Banjo Newsletter, the banjo-entry of Boucher's Glossary, The Critic article about Plantation Music, dictionary and encyclopedia entries on "Banjo" and "Slavery," an unidentified article on "The Banjo: America's Only Musical Instrument," "The 5-String Banjo in North Carolina" by C. P. Heaton, the Iron Worker Volume 18 Nr. 4, "Clawhammer Banjo Heroes: Wade Ward and Kyle Creed" by Bob Flesher, and a comic strip.

Two oversized articles on Stephen Wade by The Washington Post, and a poster for a talk by Odell "Virtual and Real Folk Music Instruments at the Smithsonian Institution" are located in oversize Box 17.

Relates to the 1960s trips and the acquisition of dulcimer now at NMAH. Also, has material that Odell provided to Grimes and her daughter to convince them that the NMAH was the best home for their collection.
Other correspondence with Anne Grimes can be found in series 1, box 1, folder 6.

The photos show posters of Fiddler Conventions and auctions (undated, 1946, 1966), as well as musicians (Charlie Higgins, Dale Poe, Wade Ward, and Luther Davies in 1965).

Contact sheets include pictures of the Melton-Russell family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains correspondence, poetry, and ephemera. Correspondence refers to family matters, political views, friends (Peter Kane Dufault, Tom Azarian, the Bread and Puppet Theater group and others). The material includes an article by John C. Dunlap, tour dates of the "Hollywood Indians" (1987), and broadsides for the bands "Screaming Broccoli" and the "Hollywood Indians." The file also includes a program for a conference on Robert Frost, two short stories by Burt Porter ("The Fiddler" and "The Long Rifle"), an article in The Burlington Free Press featuring Burt Porter (1969, in oversized Box 18), and the program and text for a Bread and Puppet Theater play "Chico Mendes" (1989).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Contains some materials that may be restricted due to privacy rights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File consists of correspondence and ephemera. Correspondence contains thoughts on family matters, political views, creative work (poetry), mutual friends (Peter Kane Dufault, Tom Azarian and others). The bulk of the poetry is by Burt Porter, with one poem by Peter Kane Dufault. The file also contains a short story named "Jase". The correspondence is accompanied by ephemera, including Porter's resume, and notes for a record, and a published excerpt of Tom Azarian's autobiography "You'll never Amount to Anything" in "Inroads - The Vermont Magazine" (1983).

Oversized posters of a performance by Tracy Schwarz and Burt Porter, and of a banjo contest are located in oversized Box 17, together with an article about a banjo performance featuring Burt Porter published in The Burlington Free Press (1978).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Contains some materials that may be restricted due to privacy rights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains articles, poetry, and correspondence (letters and printed emails) referring to family matters, political views, creative work, and mutual friends (including the Schumanns and Bread and Puppet Theater, Tom Azarian, Peter Kane Dufault, Tracy Schwarz, and others). The bulk of the poetry sent with the correspondence is by Burt Porter, with some works by Peter Kane Dufault, one poem by Burt Porter's partner Lindsay Knowlton, and one published poem by Seamus Heaney. The correspondence is accompanied by notes about Burt Porter's concert at the Home Grown Coffee House in Accokeek, M.D. (2000), as well as articles, including The Burlington Free Press (1977) featuring Burt and Torin Porter. One page with two columns ("Significant Others" and "Below the Beltway") of The Washington Post Magazine (2005), and some unidentified loose pages.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Contains some materials that may be restricted due to privacy rights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains correspondence and ephemera. Correspondence (letters and printed emails addressed to the Odells) contains family matters, political views, creative work (poetry), and mutual friends (including the Schumanns and Bread and Puppet, Evelyn Wagner, Tom Azarian, Peter Kane Dufault, Bill Royer, Ron Sanville, and others). Attached documents include an invitation to a memorial for Lucinda Porter, a drawing of "The Bobbin Mill Folks" by Skip Sedare (2007) (see subseries 8.8 (Vermont) ephemera for similar drawings), copies of the annual Bread and Puppet meeting notes (2005), a resume of Burt Porter's partner Lindsay Knowlton, and documents related to the publishing of Porter's collection of poems "A Spiral Wind" (2005). The correspondence also includes a letter to "Fellow Vermonters" sent by Vermont Senator Bernard Sanders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains articles and correspondence (letters and printed photos) concerning family matters, political views, creative work, and mutual friends (including Tom Azarian, Peter Kane Dufault, Bill Clark, the Bread and Puppet Theater group, Peter and Polly Gott, William Dowd, Tracy Schwarz, Eloise King, and others). The file also includes the February 1970 Newsletter of the Folklore Society, an article about coyotes in The Chronicle (1998), and a Bread and Puppet Theater schedule (1975).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of recordings, photographs, papers, and other materials relating to the Smithsonian Folklife Festival (formerly the Festival of American Folklife). Festival materials are concentrated on the 1976 Festival of American Folklife and the 2002 Smithsonian Folklife Festival.
Other materials related to Odell's documentation of Folklife Festivals can be found in Series 5: Publications. Related materials can also be found in the Smithsonian Institution Archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of recordings, photographs, correspondence, ephemera, writings, and other materials relating to Odell's time in Vermont. The bulk of the material relates to recording sessions with Vermont musicians, including Burt Porter (related materials can also be found in Subseries 8.6: Porter, Burt).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains letters and emails from the Sanville family, Burt Porter, Millie Gaboriault, Evelyn Wagner, Matthew Barton, Donna Hebert, and Allen Feldman, referencing the Vermont recordings and Bill Royer. Correspondence includes listening notes by Matthew Barton (American Folklife Center, Library of Congress).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains two printed publications, one program for the 2001 Banquet of the Vermont Bearhound Association, one article on the history of the Chelsea House, a folk music concert venue, referencing performances by Burt Porter and Tom Azarian. File also includes newspaper articles, three unidentified, and one obituary of Dennis George Clifford (an all around musician and friend of Judy Collins, Burt Porter, and others) published by The Chronicle on April 8th, 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains "Bear Tales and Panther Tracks" by Dorothy M. Ferrell, and "Vermonters: Oral Histories from Down Country to the Northeast Kingdom" by Ron Strickland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains The 1976/77 Official Vermont Bicentennial Guide, "You Hear the Ice Talking: The Ways of People and Ice on Lake Champlain" by I. Sheldon Posen, and "The Rowell Girls: Two Generations of a Vermont Farm Family" by Eunice and Louise Rowell Kinsey.

Oversized publications, consisting of the complete The Chronicle of March 1st, August 16th, August 30th, 1979 and July 30th 1980, and loose articles from The Chronicle of 1981, can be found in oversize Box 17.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Some CDs are located in Box 14.
